children.value: This blog is how to use Python to enable syntax highlighting in a markdown code snippet. The result is HTML/CSS that can be used and displayed on a site.
This was a solution that I was using in my old personal site/blog.
Take the code block below as an example. As of now there is no syntax highlighting.

props.code:
pip install markdown2
pip install Pygments

children.value: After installing these two packages, we will create a python file named
This snippet imports the markdown2 package, and uses it to convert the read md file (as a string), and write its contents as a HTML file.

props.code:
# test.py

import markdown2

with open("test.md","r") as f:
    text = f.read()

page =  markdown2.markdown(text,extras=['fenced-code-blocks', 'code-friendly']) 

with open('test.html', 'w') as output_file:
        output_file.write(page)

children.value: The result of this script can be seen below:

props.code:
if 
            __name__ 
            ==
             '__main__'
             :
            print
            (
            'hello world!'
            )

children.value: However, when previewing this file in your browser, it will still appear to not have any syntax highlighting. This is due to a key component being missin - CSS. This is where the python module
Open a terminal instance and enter the following commmand:
This will create a file called
. Some of its contents can be seen below (there's a lot of lines).
Next, all we need to do is add this file

props.code:
if 
            __name__ 
            ==
             '__main__'
             :
            print
            (
            'hello world!'
            )

children.value: Now when we reload the HTML file, it should have syntax highlighting!

title: Calculating nth Fibonacci Number in Linear Time

children.value: Calculating nth Fibonacci Number in Linear Time
The Fibonnaci Sequence is a series of numbers in which each number ( Fibonacci number ) is the sum of the two preceding numbers. The simplest is the series 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, etc.
Using the above defintion we can define a recursive formula for generating numbers in the fibonacci sequence as follows:
The resulting function in a program might look like:
Note: I've chosen to implement this in a Rust/Scala like fashion. Structural pattern matching is just too good. I will definitely be doing a writeup on it in the future.
For reference, the first 15 Fibonacci numbers are:
Unfortunately, calculating numbers in the fibonacci sequence using the function or formula above extremely inefficient. The time complexity of this algorithm (in terms of worst case) is
To put that in perspective, calcuating the
fibonacci number in the sequence would take:

props.code:
2 ^ 42 = 4398046511104 units of time 

(if the unit is milliseconds, it would take 50903 days!)

children.value: (if the unit is milliseconds, it would take 50903 days!)
The reason for this extremely large cost is due to recalculating values we have already seen.
As a tree, finding the 5th number of the sequence would look like the following:
As the name would suggest, tabulation relies heavily on understanding arrays.
The following snippet of code takes an array of length
(in this case our target is 15). The total complexity for this approach is
. Since all we are doing is iterating through a loop from
The array is initialized to the first and second numbers of the sequence

. From here we calculate the value of the next number of the sequence by adding the previous two numbers together. Not only is this highly-efficient in terms of time complexity when compared to the naive approach above, it is also extremely efficient in terms of memory usage. One of the issue with the recursive approach is that for each recursive call we are pushing a frame onto the stack. For a large enough value of
, this may cause a stack overflow error. In which case the program will crash.
, the output of the program displays:
If we refer to the sequence provided above, we can verify that this result is correct.
This is what is known as a "bottom-up" approach. Rather than trying to start at the target index and work our way down to our base cases
, we instead start at these cases and work our way to our target index.
